awd_titl_txt: Workshop on Musculoskeletal Biology at the 50th Annual Meeting of the Orthopedic Research Society; Midway, Utah; 22-27 July 2023
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will provide travel support for junior investigators to attend the Workshop on Musculoskeletal Biology at the 50th Annual Meeting of the Orthopedic Research Society (ORS); Midway, Utah; 22-27 July 2023. This workshop promotes interdisciplinary communication among biologists, engineers, and clinicians in the area of musculoskeletal biology, biomechanics and mechanobiology; stimulates interactions among investigators in all levels in their careers; builds for-life scientific networks; emphasizes active participation of junior faculty and students; and is unique in that discussion time equals or exceeds time allotted for presentations. The focus of the workshop is broad and highly multidisciplinary. Sessions address significant current problems, limitations, potential solutions, and approaches applicable to both basic science and clinical. The attendance of this Workshop represents a significant number of students, young investigators, women, and underrepresented minorities. Partnership with the ORS provides maximum visibility through broadcast emails and links on the ORS website, where abstracts will be posted.

The scientific theme of the 2023 workshop is "Musculoskeletal cells: identity, targeting, stimulation, and manipulation for therapeutic gain." Sessions will address significant current problems, limitations and potential solutions, and approaches applicable to both clinical and basic science. The Plenary Lecture “Remodeling in Bone” (RIB) is entitled “Bone mechanobiology: harnessing the power of skeletal loads.” Six scientific sessions will cover (1) New insights into osteoarthritis pathogenesis from single-cell -omic technologies; (2) Skeletal stem/progenitor cells; (3) Imaging mechanobiology at work; (4) Osteoclasts: origin and fate; (5) Connective tissue targeting: delivering molecules to musculoskeletal tissues; and (6) How the molecular pathophysiology of rare bone and mineral diseases informs treatment and biology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

2023 ORS Musculoskeletal Biology Workshop at Zermatt

 

The objectives of the ORS Musculoskeletal (MSK) Workshop are to improve understanding across the many disciplines that study musculoskeletal biology, provide new perspectives that lead to prevention and/or treatment of musculoskeletal diseases, and develop interdisciplinary collaborations, especially for younger scientists and scientists new to the field. The workshop receives support from the NIH, NSF, and the ASBMR.

 

In 2023, it was the 50th MSK Workshop and the 54th year since the first Workshop was held in 1965. The theme in 2023 was “New approaches to musculoskeletal tissue regeneration, quality, and targeting.” Sessions addressed significant current problems, potential limitations and solutions, and approaches applicable to both clinical and basic science, and to both young investigators entering the field and established investigators looking for updates of the current scientific knowledge. The program addressed problems beyond bone expanding to other tissues of the musculoskeletal system.

Sessions were:

  1. New insights into osteoarthritis pathogenesis from single-cell-omics technologies.
  2. Skeletal Stem/progenitor cells
  3. Imaging mechanobiology at work
  4. Osteoclasts: origin and fate
  5. Connective tissue targeting: delivering molecules to musculoskeletal tissues
  6. How the molecular pathophysiology of rare bone diseases informs treatment and biology

 

Twenty-five (25) posters were presented at the 2023 Workshop, including posters from the 10 ASBMR-Frost awards, 10 MSK-Jee awards and the OA Award.  Three separate sessions were devoted to oral presentations from the 10 winners of the ASBMR/Harold M. Frost Award, and 3 other sessions to the 10 Blue Ribbon Workshop Poster presentations.

 

This NSF award provided training and professional development opportunities through the ORS Musculoskeletal Biology Workshop. Several professional development components were built into the conference.

 

There were two Career Development workshops geared toward junior investigators. The first, chaired by Marjolein van der Meulen and Ed Guo, focused on “Postdoctoral training and junior investigators opportunities in academia: the vision of federal funding agencies: NIH, NSF, and VA”. The second, chaired by Early-career investigators Annemarie Lang and Blaine Christiansen, was titled “I got my first faculty job, with good start ups, and now what?” offering insights and an opportunity for frank discussion with peers.

 

Continuing a tradition of mentorship, lunches between young investigators and senior investigators were arranged for all Award winners, and all invited speakers were required to serve as mentors. We appointed a pre-workshop investigator mentor, Joel Boerkel, who supported the preparation of presentations by the young investigators on content and length. We continued the Blue Ribbon Poster and Presentation program in which selected posters were highlighted by 3 min-oral presentations to highlight work of young investigators and increased exposure of their work.

 

We continue to commit to equal participation of women. In 2023, 46% of the participants were women, 3 of 6 (50%) of Session Chairs were women, 2 of the 5 members of the Advisory Board are women, the RIB awardee and lecturer was a woman, and 1 of the 2 co-Chairs of the workshop is a woman. In 2023, 12% of the respondent participants were under-represented minorities including 2 African American, 4 Hispanic, 1 American Indian. For the 2023 workshop, we continued to support URMs with young investigator and travel awards.

 

The feedback from the attendees was overall positive, with 55% and 41% of responses indicating “strongly agree” or “agree” with the expectations of the conference being met. Some respondents mentioned several opportunities for improvement. These are some of the comments received for the 2023 meeting:

  1. The highly collegial atmosphere was very welcoming.
  2. Opportunities for senior investigators to get to know younger investigators.
  3. The mentor-mentee pairings were great and having a paid-for lunch was wonderful.
  4. The scientific program was outstanding, and the length of the sessions was great to promote group discussions.
  5. Adding 1-2 more presenters with shorter presenting time per session would be more dynamic.
  6. The small size of the conference allowed chances to easily speak with other scientists.
  7. Location was great, but the recreation time could be earlier in the morning to allow hiking and outdoor activities at the cooler time of the day.
  8. Shorten the evening sessions to be done by 8:30pm, as the conversations that can happen afterwards could be invaluable.
  9. Limited dining options and remote location difficult to access without a car.

10.  Great meeting, I will definitely attend again.

 

Respectfully submitted,

 

Teresita Bellido, PhD

Co-Chair, ORS Workshop on Musculoskeletal Biology at Zermatt, Midway, Utah
